choices.text: Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery
Right gastric and left gastric artery
Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels
Right gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.text: Ligation of the common hepatic artery would most likely compromise the blood supply to which of the following arteries? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery

 

Ligation of the common hepatic artery will cause impairment in the blood supply through its branches i.e., right gastric artery and right gastroepiploic artery.

 

 

  • The common hepatic artery typically divides into the hepatic proper artery and the gastroduodenal artery.
  • The hepatic proper artery, in turn, gives rise to the right gastric artery (which supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach) and continues as the left and right hepatic arteries for the liver.
  • The gastroduodenal artery gives off the right gastroepiploic artery, which supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.
  • Thus, if the common hepatic artery is ligated, blood supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries would be impaired.

 

Branches of hepatic artery (Mnemonic – Girls R So Cute)

 

  • Gastroduodenal artery > divides into right gastroepiploic and superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.
  • Right gastric artery
  • Supra duodenal artery (inconstant)
  • Cystic artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right gastric and left gastric artery: While the right gastric artery does arise from the hepatic proper artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery), the left gastric artery arises directly from the celiac trunk. Ligation of the common hepatic artery would not affect the left gastric artery's blood supply.

 

Option C. Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels: The right gastroepiploic artery arises from the gastroduodenal artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery). The short gastric arteries, however, typically arise from the splenic artery, another direct branch of the celiac trunk. Therefore, ligation of the common hepatic artery would not affect the blood supply of the short gastric vessels.

 

Option D. Right gastric and short gastric vessels: As mentioned earlier, the right gastric artery arises from the hepatic proper artery. The short gastric arteries arise from the splenic artery. Ligation of the common hepatic artery would only affect the right gastric artery's blood supply, not the short gastric vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligation of the common hepatic artery affects the blood supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries due to their derivation from the hepatic proper and gastroduodenal arteries respectively.

questions.text: Identify the vertebral level of section in given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T9

 

The provided image shows a cross-sectional anatomy where key structures such as the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs are visible. At the T9 vertebral level, the liver and stomach are seen prominently, with the heart also visible, indicating that the section is at the level where these thoracic and upper abdominal structures overlap. The presence of the lungs further supports that this is a thoracic level.

 

 

 

Cross sectional anatomy of ABDOMEN:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T10: While the T10 level also shows some of the same structures, the visibility and position of the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs in this image are more indicative of T9.

 

Option C. T11: At the T11 level, the kidneys start to become visible, and the heart is usually not as prominent as it is at the T9 level.

 

Option D. T12: The T12 level typically shows the kidneys more clearly and does not include as much of the heart and upper liver as seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The T9 vertebral level in cross-sectional anatomy images often shows the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs, making it a key point for identifying these structures.

questions.text: Which of the marked foramen does the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve pass through? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 3 (Foramen rotundum)

 

Explanation:

 

  • Transmits maxillary nerve (V2)
  • Located in greater wing of sphenoid bone
  • Connects middle cranial fossa to pterygopalatine fossa
  • Important for maxillary sensory distribution

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10:

 

  • Different foramen in skull base
  • Not related to trigeminal nerve divisions
  • Not in the path of V2

 

Option B. 5:

 

  • Not in the pathway of maxillary nerve
  • Different anatomical location
  • Serves other neurovascular structures

 

Option D. 4 (Foramen ovale):

 

  • Transmits mandibular nerve (V3)
  • Located in greater wing of sphenoid
  • Not the path for maxillary division
  • Serves different division of trigeminal nerve

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding trigeminal nerve divisions and their foramina: 
    • V1 (Ophthalmic): Superior orbital fissure
    • V2 (Maxillary): Foramen rotundum
    • V3 (Mandibular): Foramen ovale
  • Clinical significance: 
    • Trigeminal neuralgia
    • Sensory distribution
    • Local anesthetic blocks
    • Surgical approaches to skull base

questions.text: How many intrinsic muscles of the hand are supplied by the median nerve? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans: A. 5

 

Explanation:

 

  • The median nerve supplies 5 intrinsic hand muscles: 
    1. Opponens pollicis
    2. Abductor pollicis brevis
    3. Flexor pollicis brevis (superficial head)
    4. First lumbrical
    5. Second lumbrical

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 13:

 

  • This number exceeds the actual count of median nerve-innervated intrinsic muscles
  • More characteristic of combined thenar and hypothenar muscles

 

Option C. 15:

 

  • This is the number of intrinsic muscles supplied by ulnar nerve
  • Includes hypothenar muscles, most lumbricals, and all interossei

 

Option D. 17:

 

  • Exceeds total number of intrinsic hand muscles
  • Not anatomically accurate

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding intrinsic hand muscle innervation: 
    • Median nerve: 5 muscles (primarily thenar)
    • Ulnar nerve: 15 muscles (hypothenar, interossei, most lumbricals)
  • Clinical significance: 
    • Median nerve compression (Carpal tunnel syndrome)
    • Ape hand deformity
    • Thenar wasting
    • Hand muscle testing

questions.text: What type of joint is demonstrated in the highlighted region of the vertebral articulation shown? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Synovial

 

The joint marked in the above image is a synovial joint called the costotransverse and costovertebral joint.

 

These are the most common type of joints in the body. The articulating ends of the bones in these joints are covered with articular cartilage. These bones are enclosed within an articular capsule which has an outer fibrous layer (giving it strength) and an inner synovial membrane which secretes synovial fluid (providing lubrication and nutrients to the joint). Examples include the knee joint, elbow joint, and many others.

 

They are diarthrotic, meaning they are freely movable. The exact range of movement and type of movement (e.g., hinge, pivot, ball-and-socket) varies depending on the specific joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: This is a type of fibrous joint where the bones are joined by a ligament or a membrane. The most commonly referred syndesmosis is the one between the tibia and fibula in the leg, held together by the interosseous membrane and the anterior and posterior tibiofibular ligaments.

 

  • It allows for a slight movement (making it amphiarthrotic), particularly when the foot is dorsiflexed or plantarflexed.

 

Option B. Synarthrosis: This term describes a joint that allows very minimal or no movement. It encompasses several types of joints including sutures (between skull bones), gomphoses (between a tooth and its socket), and synchondroses (which we'll discuss next).

 

  • These are largely immovable joints. They serve to provide stability in certain areas of the body, like the skull, where movement is not desired.

 

Option C. Synchondrosis: This is a subtype of synarthrosis, and it's a type of cartilaginous joint where bones are joined together by hyaline cartilage. A classic example is the joint between the first rib and the sternum, or the epiphyseal plates in growing bones.

 

  • They are immovable (synarthrotic). The primary purpose of these joints is to allow growth of the bone while providing stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Description of the joint present in the thoracic region are as follows:

choices.text: Fingers are held in mild extension
Most common involvement is index finger

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding De Quervain's tenosynovitis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It affects APL and EPB

 

De Quervain's tenosynovitis involves inflammation of the sheaths of the extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL) tendons. These tendons run side by side and are located on the radial side of the wrist, traveling through a tunnel (sheath) that can become narrowed due to the inflammation, causing pain especially with thumb and wrist movement.

 

 

Finkelstein's test: On grasping the patient's thumb and quickly abducting the hand ulnar ward, the pain over the radial styloid tip is excruciating. It's the most pathognomonic objective sign but is also seen in other conditions like radial nerve entrapment and arthritis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fingers are held in mild extension: This statement is not typically associated with De Quervain's tenosynovitis. Instead, the thumb is often held in a position of abduction away from the hand to minimize pain. The condition mainly affects the tendons and their sheaths at the base of the thumb, not the fingers.

 

Option C. Most common involvement is index finger: This is incorrect. De Quervain's tenosynovitis primarily affects the base of the thumb. While pain can radiate and might be felt in the nearby areas, including the forearm or even the index finger, the primary site of involvement is the tendons at the thumb's base, not the index finger itself.

 

Option D. Treatment is surgery: While surgery can be an option for De Quervain's tenosynovitis, it is generally considered when conservative treatments fail. Most cases of De Quervain's can be treated conservatively with methods such as: Rest and immobilization using splints, Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain and inflammation , Corticosteroid injections into the tendon sheath to reduce inflammation and Physical therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A maid in the house presented in the clinic with complaint of pain & swelling at the knee. Which bursa is involved in this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

Explanation:

 

The maid's complaint of pain and swelling at the knee is indicative of bursitis. In this specific case, the bursa involved is the prepatellar bursa, labelled as B in the image.

The prepatellar bursa is located in front of the patella (kneecap). The term "housemaid's knee" is commonly used to describe prepatellar bursitis, which is inflammation of the prepatellar bursa. This condition is typically caused by repetitive kneeling, which is common in individuals who perform frequent cleaning or other activities that require prolonged kneeling.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  A: This indicates the suprapatellar bursa, located above the patella. It is not typically associated with "housemaid's knee."

 

Option C. C: This indicates the subcutaneous infrapatellar bursa, located below the patella, which is associated with "clergyman's knee" due to repeated kneeling in a kneeling position.

 

 

Option D. D: This indicates the deep infrapatellar bursa, also located below the patella, but deeper and not typically involved in "housemaid's knee."

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prepatellar bursa, located in front of the patella, is the bursa involved in "housemaid's knee" (prepatellar bursitis).

questions.text: Which ganglia is affected due to the involvement of the nerve located at the marked area? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pterygopalatine ganglia

 

The marked area on the skull image points to a region near the pterygoid plates and the palatine bone, specifically associated with the pterygopalatine fossa. This fossa houses the pterygopalatine ganglion, which is responsible for relaying parasympathetic nerve fibers from the facial nerve to the lacrimal glands, nasal glands, and palatine glands.

 

The pterygopalatine ganglion is located within the pterygopalatine fossa, a small space beneath the apex of the orbit, posterior to the maxilla. The ganglion receives preganglionic parasympathetic fibers from the greater petrosal nerve, a branch of the facial nerve, and is involved in various autonomic functions related to the glands in the region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Submandibular ganglia: This ganglion is located below the mandible and is associated with the submandibular and sublingual glands. It is not related to the region marked in the image, which is closer to the pterygopalatine fossa.

 

Option B. Ciliary ganglia: The ciliary ganglion is located in the orbit and is associated with the eye, specifically controlling the ciliary muscle and the sphincter pupillae. It is not related to the marked area on the skull image.

 

Option D. Otic ganglia: The otic ganglion is associated with the parotid gland and is located just below the foramen ovale. While it plays a role in salivary secretion, it is not connected to the region indicated in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterygopalatine ganglion is located in the pterygopalatine fossa and is involved in the parasympathetic innervation of the lacrimal, nasal, and palatine glands. This ganglion is specifically affected by involvement in the region marked in the skull image.

questions.text: Identify the liver segment star marked in the image below:  (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. V

 

Segment V of the liver is highlighted in green in this CT scan. The CT section shown is taken below the portal vein, allowing a cross-section of the portal vein before its bifurcation to be seen.

 

A horizontal plane known as the portal plane divides the liver where the portal vein bifurcates and becomes horizontal. This divides each section of the liver into superior and inferior segments:

 

  • Left lateral section: segment II above and segment III below the portal plane
  • Left medial section: segment IVa above and segment Ib below the portal plane
  • Right anterior (or medial) section: segment VIll above and segment V below the portal plane
  • Right posterior (or lateral section): segment VIl above and segment VI below the portal plane

 

Other Options:

 

Option B (IVa): Incorrect because Segment IVa is located in the left medial section of the liver and is positioned above the portal plane. This segment does not correlate with the green highlighted area in the provided image.

 

Option C (VII): Incorrect as Segment VII is part of the right posterior (or lateral) section of the liver and is located above the portal plane, unlike the depicted segment.

 

Option D (I): Incorrect because Segment I, also known as the caudate lobe, is uniquely positioned and does not conform to the typical left-right segmentation. It is not visible in the typical transverse sections used for identifying other segments like V.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Median

 

  • The uvula vesicae is formed by the prostate's median lobe.
  • The uvula vesicae is a slight elevation on the trigone immediately posterior to the urethral orifice caused by the median lobe of the prostate.
  • In benign prostatic hypertrophy, it is frequently enlarged.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior: The anterior lobe of the prostate, also referred to as the anterior fibromuscular stroma, is found at the front of the prostate, facing the pubic symphysis. Contrary to the other sections of the prostate, this area is primarily made up of fibromuscular tissue and contains fewer glandular elements. It doesn't commonly give rise to clinical conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or prostate cancer.

 

Option B. Posterior: The posterior lobe is located at the back of the prostate, facing the rectum. This part of the prostate is significant clinically because it's the most common site for the development of prostate cancer. During a digital rectal exam, the physician can palpate this lobe, and any firm or irregular nodules felt here could suggest malignancy.

 

Option D. Lateral: The lateral lobes are the large bilateral portions of the prostate on either side of the urethra. These are the most voluminous parts of the prostate and are typically the primary sites involved in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a common condition in older men where the prostate enlarges and can cause urinary obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle lobe or median lobe of the prostate is situated between the ejaculatory ducts and the urethra. When the median lobe enlarges due to conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), it can project into the bladder, forming a structure called the "uvula vesicae." It is also known as Lietaud’s uvula. This growth can cause urinary symptoms by obstructing the bladder neck.

questions.text: Which deformity is shown in this image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cubitus valgus

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts an outward deviation of the forearm, which is known as cubitus valgus. In a normal carrying angle, there is a slight outward angulation at the elbow joint, which is more prominent in females. However, in cubitus valgus, the forearm deviates excessively outward, beyond the normal range. This condition is generally associated with ulnar nerve injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cubitus varus: Cubitus varus is the opposite of cubitus valgus, where the forearm deviates inward. This condition is also known as gunstock deformity and is often seen in supracondylar fractures of the humerus, where median nerve injury may also be present.

 

Option C. Gunstock deformity: Gunstock deformity is another term for cubitus varus, where the forearm deviates inward, resembling the shape of a gunstock. This is not the deformity shown in the given image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cubitus valgus is an outward deviation of the forearm at the elbow joint, beyond the normal carrying angle, and is generally associated with ulnar nerve injury.

questions.text: A lesion involving Brodmann area 22 is most likely to result in which of the following deficits? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Receptive aphasia

 

Broadmann’s area 22 corresponds to Wernicke’s area, which is primarily involved in language comprehension. A lesion in this area leads to receptive aphasia, also known as sensory or Wernicke’s aphasia. In receptive aphasia, patients have difficulty understanding spoken language, and their speech may be fluent but lacks meaning or coherence. They can produce words but often speak in nonsensical phrases or sentences that are difficult to understand, indicating a disruption in the processing of language comprehension.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Poor repetition of language: This is associated with conduction aphasia, which occurs due to a lesion in the arcuate fasciculus that connects Broca's and Wernicke's areas. It is characterized by an inability to repeat words or phrases accurately.

 

Option C. Expressive aphasia: This is also known as Broca’s aphasia, resulting from a lesion in Broadmann’s areas 44 and 45. Patients with expressive aphasia have difficulty producing speech, characterized by slow, halting, and effortful speech, but their comprehension remains intact.

 

Option D. Poor naming: Poor naming is typically observed in anomic aphasia, which occurs when the connection between language processing centers is disrupted, but it is not specific to a lesion in Broadmann’s area 22.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in Broadmann’s area 22, known as Wernicke’s area, leads to receptive aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension.

choices.text: Formed by the internal oblique aponeurosis and transversus abdominis aponeurosis
Forms the posterior wall of inguinal canal
Protects the superficial inguinal ring to maintain integrity of inguinal canal
Runs parallel to the inguinal ligament

questions.text: For the conjoint tendon, all are true except:  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Runs parallel to the inguinal ligament

 

Explanation:

 

The conjoint tendon does not run parallel to the inguinal ligament. Instead, it runs obliquely and inserts into the pubic crest and pectineal line, thereby reinforcing the posterior wall of the inguinal canal but not parallel to the inguinal ligament.

 

The conjoint tendon, also known as the falx inguinalis, is a critical structure in the anatomy of the inguinal region. It is formed by the aponeuroses of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles. This structure plays an essential role in maintaining the integrity of the inguinal canal and preventing hernias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formed by the internal oblique aponeurosis and transversus abdominis aponeurosis: This statement is true. The conjoint tendon is indeed formed by the fusion of the internal oblique aponeurosis and the transversus abdominis aponeurosis.

 

Option B. Forms the posterior wall of the inguinal canal: This statement is also true. The conjoint tendon contributes significantly to the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, providing support and reinforcing this area.

 

Option C. Protects the superficial inguinal ring to maintain integrity of inguinal canal: This statement is true. The conjoint tendon helps protect the superficial inguinal ring by forming a shutter-like mechanism that reduces the risk of inguinal hernias by maintaining the canal's integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The conjoint tendon is formed by the internal oblique and transversus abdominis aponeuroses and plays a crucial role in reinforcing the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and protecting the superficial inguinal ring. It does not run parallel to the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tributary of the inferior vena cava? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left inferior phrenic vein

 

 

The left inferior phrenic vein is a direct tributary of the inferior vena cava. Both the right and left inferior phrenic veins drain into the inferior vena cava.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left suprarenal vein: The left suprarenal vein does not drain directly into the inferior vena cava. Instead, it drains into the left renal vein, which then drains into the inferior vena cava.

 

Option C. Left gonadal vein: Similar to the left suprarenal vein, the left gonadal vein (whether it is the testicular vein in males or the ovarian vein in females) drains into the left renal vein before it reaches the inferior vena cava.

 

Option D. Right ascending lumbar vein: The right ascending lumbar vein is not a direct tributary of the inferior vena cava. It usually joins with the subcostal vein to form the azygos vein on the right side, which then drains into the superior vena cava.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tributaries of the inferior vena cava include veins that drain directly into it without first passing through another vein, except for the hepatic veins.

questions.text:
Which of the following are a part of the limbic system?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Amygdala

2. Hippocampus

3. Thalamus
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1, 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

The limbic system is a complex set of brain structures located on both sides of the thalamus, immediately beneath the cerebrum. It includes key components such as the amygdala, hippocampus, thalamus, hypothalamus, basal ganglia, and cingulate gyrus. These structures support a variety of functions related to emotions, behavior, motivation, long-term memory, and olfaction.

 

  1. Amygdala: Integral for processing emotions, the amygdala is especially involved in fear, anxiety, and social cognition. It also plays a significant role in forming and retrieving emotional memories.
  2. Hippocampus: Essential for learning and memory, the hippocampus is pivotal in the consolidation of information from short-term memory to long-term memory and spatial navigation.
  3. Thalamus: Although primarily known as the relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex, the thalamus also supports functions of the limbic system by regulating consciousness, sleep, and alertness.

 

Other structures are :

 

The hypothalamus is involved in regulating many bodily functions, including hunger, thirst, body temperature, and circadian rhythms. It also plays a key role in the regulation of the autonomic nervous system and the endocrine system.

 

The cingulate gyrus is involved in a variety of functions, including emotion regulation, attention, and the processing of pain.

 

Together, these structures form a complex network that plays a crucial role in many aspects of human behavior and cognition. Dysfunction or damage to the limbic system can lead to a range of neurological and psychiatric disorders, including Alzheimer's disease, depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The limbic system’s role is critical, as its structures are deeply integrated into the processes governing emotions, memory, and essential physiological functions. Damage or dysfunction in any part of the limbic system can lead to profound psychological and cognitive impairments, affecting everything from emotional regulation to memory processing.

questions.text: Which skull foramen is formed by 3 bones?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Foramen lacerum

 

Explanation:

 

The foramen lacerum is a triangular-shaped foramen located in the skull base. It is largely filled with cartilage in a living individual and serves as a landmark rather than a conduit for significant neurovascular structures (though some smaller emissary veins and nerves might pass through). Importantly, the internal carotid artery courses superiorly to this foramen but doesn't pass through it. The foramen lacerum is bordered by three bones:

 

  • Petrous part of the temporal bone: This bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • Sphenoid bone: The greater wing of the sphenoid bone forms the anterior and lateral aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • Basilar part of the occipital bone: The basilar part of the occipital bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.

 

The foramen lacerum is covered by a fibrous membrane, which makes it difficult to see and access.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foramen magnum: The foramen magnum is the largest foramen of the skull and is located in its base. Through it pass the medulla oblongata (which becomes the spinal cord as it exits the skull), the vertebral arteries, spinal parts of the accessory nerves, and the anterior and posterior spinal arteries. It is formed entirely by the occipital bone.

 

Option C. Foramen rotundum: The foramen rotundum is located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. Through this foramen, the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve (V2) exits the cranial cavity to enter the pterygopalatine fossa. It is formed solely by the sphenoid bone.

 

Option D. Foramen jugulare (jugular foramen): The jugular foramen is a large irregular opening located between the petrous part of the temporal bone and the occipital bone. This foramen transmits the internal jugular vein and several cranial nerves: the glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), and accessory (XI) nerves. It is formed by two bones:

 

  1. Anterolaterally: the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  2. Posteromedially: the occipital bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The foramen lacerum's formation by three bones (the petrous part of the temporal bone, greater wing of the sphenoid bone, and basilar part of the occipital bone) makes it unique among the foramina at the base of the skull. Understanding its anatomical context and relations is crucial for interpreting imaging and planning surgeries involving the cranial base.

questions.text: A patient presented with paradoxical respiration. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. D

 

Explanation:

 

Paradoxical respiration occurs due to the damage of the phrenic nerve, which is marked as D, in the given image.

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

A. Right vagus nerve

B. Left vagus nerve

C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve (inferior laryngeal nerve)

D. Right phrenic nerve

 

 

The phrenic nerve provides motor innervation to the diaphragm, the primary muscle of inspiration. Damage or paralysis of one phrenic nerve can cause one hemidiaphragm to rise during inspiration instead of descending as it normally does, leading to paradoxical movement. This is especially noticeable when the patient is in a supine position. If the right phrenic nerve is affected, the right hemidiaphragm will exhibit this paradoxical movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right vagus nerve: The vagus nerve (10th cranial nerve) has a broad distribution and is involved in the parasympathetic innervation of many organs in the thorax and abdomen. It also provides sensory innervation to the larynx, trachea, esophagus, and a portion of the external ear. It doesn't innervate the diaphragm directly for its motor function.

 

Option B. Left vagus nerve: Similarly to the right vagus, the left vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to many thoracic and abdominal organs but does not control diaphragmatic contractions.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve (inferior laryngeal nerve): This is a branch of the vagus nerve that innervates most intrinsic muscles of the larynx. The recurrent laryngeal nerve is important for vocal cord function. Damage to this nerve can lead to hoarseness or voice changes but does not directly affect respiratory mechanics in the manner described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical movements in the chest are as follows:

 

  • Paradoxical respiration - the aberrant contraction of the abdomen or chest walls, which causes them to move in rather than out during inhalation. It appears in the flail chest.

 

Paradoxical movement of the diaphragm - Normally, during inspiration, the diaphragm descends. Yet, due to diaphragmatic paralysis in phrenic nerve palsy cases, the affected side of the diaphragm moves upward (paradoxical breathing). The gold standard test to find this is to stimulate the phrenic nerve electrically or magnetically while simultaneously recording the transdiaphragmatic pressure and/or the compound muscle action potential. Both fluoroscopy and ultrasonography can show this.

questions.text: Dura sac ends at which vertebral level? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. C) S2

 

Explanation:

 

The posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) is a bony projection located at the posterior end of the iliac crest. It is situated at the level of the S2 vertebra. This anatomical landmark is identifiable by a dimple that is approximately 4 cm lateral to the second sacral spine, situated above the medial gluteal region.

 

It is an important landmark where dura sac ends.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L5: The L5 vertebra corresponds to the transtubercular plane and the confluence of common iliac veins, not the PIIS.

 

Option B. S1: The S1 vertebra marks the level of the sacral promontory, which is superior to the PIIS.

 

Option D. S3: The S2 vertebra corresponds to the posterior inferior iliac spine, not the posterior superior iliac spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the anatomical landmark where duramater ends that corresponds to posterior superior iliac spine i.e. S2.

questions.text: The ureteric bud arises from which of the following embryological structures? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mesonephric duct

 

The ureteric bud arises from the mesonephric (or Wolffian) duct. The mesonephric duct is one of the primary structures in the early embryonic development of the urinary and reproductive systems. The ureteric bud's growth is stimulated by signals from the adjacent metanephrogenic blastema. The ureteric bud undergoes repeated branching to form the ureter, renal pelvis, calyces, and the collecting tubules of the kidneys.

 

  • The intermediate mesoderm is a specific type of mesoderm that is located between the paraxial mesoderm and lateral plate.
  • During development, it plays a crucial role in the formation of both the urogenital system and the reproductive system. It divides into two structures known as the genital ridge and nephrogenic cord.
  • The nephrogenic cord goes on to form three distinct structures - the pronephros, mesonephros, and metanephros. From the mesonephros, the ureteric bud develops and eventually fuses with the mesonephric duct.
  • The metanephros then proliferates around the ureteric bud, forming what is called the metanephric blastema. This ultimately gives rise to the definitive kidneys.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metanephros: The metanephros is the embryological structure that develops into the permanent kidney in humans. The metanephrogenic blastema (or metanephrogenic mesenchyme) is the tissue that surrounds the tip of the ureteric bud and interacts with it. Signals from the ureteric bud stimulate the metanephrogenic blastema to differentiate into the nephron components of the kidney (like the glomerulus, proximal tubule, loop of Henle, etc.). The metanephros is not the origin of the ureteric bud but rather interacts with it.

 

Option C. Pronephros: The pronephros is the most primitive of the three embryonic kidneys. It appears early in embryonic development but quickly degenerates and is non-functional in mammals. Its duct, the pronephric duct, eventually becomes the mesonephric duct when the mesonephros starts to develop. The pronephros itself does not give rise to the ureteric bud.

 

Option D. Genital sinus: The genital sinus is involved in the development of the lower parts of the reproductive system and parts of the urinary system. In females, it contributes to parts of the vagina, and in males, it contributes to parts of the urethra. It does not give rise to the ureteric bud.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

A. Dorsal views of the bladder showing the relation of the ureters and mesonephric ducts during development. Initially the ureters are formed by an outgrowth of the mesonephric duct

 

B-D. with time they assume a separate entrance into the urinary bladder

 

C and D. Note the trigone of the bladder formed by incorporation of the mesonephric ducts

questions.text: A patient is unable to abduct his arm. Which of the following root values is likely to be affected? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C5

 

Explanation:

 

The most likely cause of the inability to abduct the arm is a C5 root lesion.

 

The C5 spinal nerve plays a crucial role in controlling shoulder abduction. It gives rise to the axillary nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle. Damage or compression of the C5 nerve root or axillary nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to difficulty in abducting the arm.

 

Deltoid is supplied by axillary nerve which has the root value of C4-C6. The C5 component is responsible for abduction.Other components help in flexion and extensionm at shoulder joint

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C4: The C4 spinal nerve does not directly innervate the muscles responsible for shoulder abduction. It primarily supplies sensory information to areas of the neck and upper shoulders.

 

Option C. C6: The C6 spinal nerve primarily innervates the muscles responsible for elbow flexion and wrist extension, not shoulder abduction. Damage to the C6 nerve root would affect these functions rather than shoulder abduction.

 

Option D. C7: The C7 spinal nerve primarily innervates the muscles responsible for elbow and wrist flexion and finger extension. It is not directly involved in shoulder abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of the shoulder

questions.text: Superior gluteal nerve supplies all of the following structures except:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Piriformis

 

All of the structures except pyriformis are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Pyriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis.

 

The superior gluteal nerve is a nerve that originates from the dorsal branches of the L4, L5, and S1 spinal nerves. It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle and provides motor innervation to the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles. The superior gluteal vessels also accompany the nerve.

 

The nerve to the piriformis, on the other hand, arises from the dorsal branches of the S1 and S2 spinal nerves. It passes through or underneath the piriformis muscle and provides motor innervation to the piriformis muscle itself.

 

Damage or compression to the superior gluteal nerve can result in weakness or atrophy of the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles, leading to difficulty with hip abduction and stabilization. Compression of the nerve to the piriformis can result in piriformis syndrome, a condition in which the piriformis muscle irritates or compresses the nerve, causing pain and numbness in the buttock and leg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluteus medius: The superior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus medius muscle. This muscle is important for hip abduction and stabilization of the hip joint, especially during activities like walking and running.

 

Option B. Gluteus minimus: Similar to the gluteus medius, the superior gluteal nerve also supplies the gluteus minimus muscle. This muscle is located deep to the gluteus medius and assists in hip abduction and stabilization.

 

Option D. Tensor fasciae latae: The superior gluteal nerve supplies the tensor fasciae latae muscle. This muscle helps in flexing, abducting, and medially rotating the hip joint. It also assists in stabilizing the pelvis when standing on one leg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The piriformis muscle is not supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Instead, it is primarily innervated by the branches of the sacral plexus, specifically the ventral rami of S1 and S2. The piriformis muscle plays a role in external hip rotation.

questions.text: A boy with a history of a fall from a tree presents with a lurching gait and dragging of his feet. Which of the following structures are involved? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Explanation:

 

The structure involved in causing lurching gait in the child is gluteus medius (marked as 2). The gluteus medius muscle is critical for stabilizing the pelvis during gait. When functioning normally, it prevents the pelvis from dropping to the opposite side during the swing phase of the walk. If injured or dysfunctional, such as might occur from a traumatic fall, the ability to maintain pelvic stability is compromised, leading to a lurching gait, known clinically as a Trendelenburg gait.

 

 

The structure shown in the image are :

 

1-Gluteus maximus

2-Gluteus medius

3-Piriformis

4-Sciatic nerve

 

Other Options:

 

1. Gluteus Maximus: The largest and most superficial of the gluteal muscles, mainly responsible for extension and lateral rotation of the hip. Its involvement is more related to power movements like climbing or jumping rather than gait stability.

 

3. Piriformis: A small muscle located deep in the buttock, behind the gluteus maximus. It helps with lateral rotation of the hip. Although it is near the sciatic nerve, it is less likely involved in producing a lurching gait unless it compresses the sciatic nerve, causing sciatica.

 

4. Sciatic Nerve: The largest nerve in the body, running from the lower back to the feet. While injury to this nerve can cause pain and weakness in the legs, it typically would not cause a lurching gait unless there is significant associated muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical Insight:

 

Injury to the gluteus medius or the superior gluteal nerve can lead to an inability to properly abduct the hip on the stance side, resulting in a drop of the pelvis on the contralateral side when the affected leg is weight-bearing. This is often demonstrated by a positive Trendelenburg sign and manifests as a compensatory lurch toward the affected side to maintain balance.

 

Additional Information

 

Gluteus medius and minimus are powerful abductors of the hip joint. Mechanism of actions of gluteus medius and minimus-

 

  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in a slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
  • The actions of these muscles are affected when there is an injury to the superior gluteal nerve, neck of the femur, or loss of normal angulation of the shaft of the femur. This occurs in conditions like paralysis of the glutei, developmental dysplasia of the hip, etc.
  • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb. This leads to a positive Trendelenburg's sign with a characteristic lurching gait - the patient lurches towards the affected side with contralateral pelvis drop.

choices.text: Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight
Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the skin is false ? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dermis is derived from ectoderm

 

Dermis is derived from mesoderm and epidermis is derived from ectoderm.

 

  • The epidermis is derived from the ectoderm, which is one of the three primary germ layers that form during embryonic development.
  • The ectoderm gives rise to the skin, hair, nails, and the nervous system.
  • The epidermis itself is formed by the surface ectoderm, which begins to thicken and form a layer of cells called the basal layer.
  • On the other hand, the dermis is derived from the mesoderm, which is another one of the primary germ layers.
  • The mesoderm gives rise to a number of different structures in the body, including muscles, bones, and connective tissue.
  • The dermis itself is formed from the mesenchymal cells that migrate into the developing skin from the mesoderm.
  • These cells differentiate into fibroblasts, which then produce the extracellular matrix that forms the dermis.
  • During development, the epidermis and dermis layers interact and become tightly integrated.
  • As the epidermis differentiates, it sends signals to the underlying mesenchymal cells to produce the dermis, and the two layers eventually become fully functional together as the skin.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight: This statement is generally accurate. In adults, the skin weighs about 8-10 pounds and has a surface area of about 2 square meters. The skin is the largest organ of the body, and its weight can be roughly estimated to be around 15% of the total body weight, although this can vary based on individuals and their body compositions.

 

Option C. Epidermis is derived from ectoderm: This statement is true. The epidermis is the outermost layer of the skin and is indeed derived from the ectoderm during embryonic development. It's a stratified squamous epithelium that mainly consists of keratinocytes in progressive stages of differentiation, from the basal layer to the surface. The epidermis provides the body with a barrier against pathogens, UV radiation, and water loss.

 

Option D. Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen: This statement is true. The dermis, which provides the skin's strength and elasticity, primarily consists of type 1 collagen, but it also contains a smaller amount of type 3 collagen, especially in the papillary dermis (the uppermost layer of the dermis). These collagens are essential for skin's resilience and durability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dermis is derived from the mesoderm, not the ectoderm.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with visual disturbances. An MRI reveals a lesion at the location marked in the image. Which of the following visual field defects is most likely associated with this lesion? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bitemporal hemianopia

 

The lesion refers to a craniopharyngioma, a tumor that arises from the remnants of Rathke's pouch, located near the pituitary gland.

 

Craniopharyngiomas are commonly found near the optic chiasm, where the crossing of the nasal fibers of the optic nerves occurs. When this tumor grows, it can compress the optic chiasm, leading to bitemporal hemianopia. This condition results in the loss of peripheral vision in both eyes because the tumor specifically damages the nasal fibers, which are responsible for peripheral vision.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single vision field loss: Single vision field loss would occur with damage to the optic nerve on one side, not at the optic chiasm. Craniopharyngiomas typically affect both nasal fibers at the chiasm, leading to a specific pattern of vision loss, not confined to a single visual field.

 

Option C. Complete blindness: Complete blindness would require extensive damage to the entire visual pathway, which is not typical of craniopharyngioma unless the tumor has become exceptionally large and invasive. The usual presentation is partial vision loss, particularly affecting the peripheral fields.

 

Option D. Homonymous hemianopia: Homonymous hemianopia occurs when there is damage to the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations, or occipital cortex on one side, leading to loss of the same visual field in both eyes. This pattern does not fit with craniopharyngioma, which specifically affects the optic chiasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopharyngiomas commonly cause bitemporal hemianopia due to compression of the optic chiasm, resulting in peripheral vision loss on both sides.

questions.text: A surgical procedure is performed on the great saphenous vein located 2.5 cm anterior to the medial malleolus. Which nerve should be prevented from damage during the ligature? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Saphenous nerve

 

The saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body. It accompanies the great saphenous vein, running anterior to the medial malleolus before it supplies sensation to the medial side of the leg and foot. During surgical procedures involving the great saphenous vein, particularly at the site near the medial malleolus, the saphenous nerve is at risk of injury. Damage to this nerve can result in sensory loss along its distribution, which includes the medial aspect of the foot and lower leg.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sural nerve: The sural nerve is located posterior to the lateral malleolus and is not involved in the area anterior to the medial malleolus, making it unlikely to be injured during this particular procedure.

 

Option B. Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve runs deeper and posterior to the medial malleolus. It is not in close proximity to the great saphenous vein at the described location, so it is not the nerve at risk in this scenario.

 

Option C. Deep peroneal nerve: The deep peroneal nerve runs along the anterior compartment of the leg and provides sensation to the web space between the first and second toes. It does not accompany the great saphenous vein and is not at risk in the described procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The saphenous nerve accompanies the great saphenous vein near the medial malleolus and is at risk of injury during surgical procedures in this region.

questions.text: A patient cannot identify objects but she can see the color, texture, shape. What is the site of the lesion? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occipital area

 

 

The patient’s symptoms indicate a condition known as visual agnosia, where there is an inability to recognize objects despite having intact vision for color, texture, and shape. This suggests that the primary visual cortex (area 17) is functioning properly, but the secondary visual processing areas (areas 18 and 19) are affected.

 

  • Occipital Area: The occipital lobe, specifically Brodmann areas 18 and 19, are responsible for the higher-order processing of visual information. Lesions in these areas can result in visual agnosia, where the patient can see but cannot interpret or recognize visual stimuli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial parietal area: The medial parietal area is not primarily  involved in visual recognition.

 

Option B. Lateral parietal area: The lateral parietal area is not involved in the direct processing of visual information.

 

Option C. Infra temporal area: The infra temporal area is not involved in the direct processing of visual information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesions in the secondary visual processing areas (areas 18 and 19) of the occipital lobe can result in visual agnosia, where the patient can see but cannot identify objects.

questions.text: In given image, nucleus of marked nerve is related to (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervical spinal segment

 

The nerve marked in the image is the phrenic nerve. The phrenic nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the diaphragm, which is crucial for breathing. The mnemonic "3, 4, 5 keeps the diaphragm alive" helps to remember that the phrenic nerve arises from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5. This nerve travels downward, passing in front of the lung root, to reach the diaphragm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain: The midbrain is not involved in the origin of the phrenic nerve. The midbrain primarily deals with functions such as vision, hearing, motor control, sleep/wake, arousal, and temperature regulation.

 

Option B. Pons: The pons is involved in various functions including breathing, communication between different parts of the brain, and sensations such as hearing, taste, and balance. However, it does not give rise to the phrenic nerve.

 

Option C. Medulla: The medulla oblongata regulates vital functions such as heart rate, breathing, and blood pressure. While it contains nuclei for several cranial nerves, it is not the origin of the phrenic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phrenic nerve originates from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5, and is essential for diaphragm movement and breathing.

questions.text: Indicated structure gives origin to which of the following fiber (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dentato-rubral

 

The indicated structure in the provided image is the dentate nucleus. The dentate nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei and is the largest and most lateral of these nuclei. It is involved in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements.

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers. These fibers project from the dentate nucleus to the red nucleus in the midbrain, playing a crucial role in the coordination of motor movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebello-rubral: Incorrect because while it involves the cerebellum and red nucleus, the correct specific term for the fiber originating from the dentate nucleus is "dentato-rubral."

 

Option B. Cerebello-reticul: Incorrect because this option refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the reticular formation, not specifically involving the dentate nucleus.

 

Option C. Cerebello-vestibul: Incorrect because this refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the vestibular nuclei, which are involved in balance and spatial orientation, not related to the dentate nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers, which project to the red nucleus and are crucial for motor coordination.

questions.text: Identify the structures marked in numbers.  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-liver, 2-pancrease, 3-spleen

 

Explanation:

 

In the provided CT scan of the abdomen, three structures are marked -

 

  1. The first structure (marked as "1") is identified as the liver. This identification is based on its large size and position on the right side of the vertebral column. The liver is a prominent organ in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, adjacent to the anterior abdominal wall.
  2. The second structure (marked as "2") is the pancreas. Specifically, this is the head of the pancreas. The pancreas lies in the retroperitoneal space, with its head nestled in the curve of the duodenum and its tail extending towards the hilum of the spleen.
  3. The third structure (marked as "3") is the spleen. The spleen is located in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen, near the stomach and under the left diaphragm. It is typically a crescent-shaped organ.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following structures are derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Linea semilunaris

 

Linea semilunaris is derived from the aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle.

 

The linea semilunaris is a curved tendinous line located on either side of the rectus abdominis muscle, representing the lateral border where the flat abdominal muscles' aponeuroses come together.

 

It is not derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique alone. Instead, it is formed where the aponeurosis of the external oblique, the internal oblique, and the transversus abdominis meet and fuse before they envelop the rectus abdominis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectineal Ligament: Also known as Cooper's ligament, the pectineal ligament is a fibrous band that runs parallel and posterior to the inguinal ligament, extending from the pubic tubercle to the pectineal line of the pubis. While it is closely related to structures formed by the aponeurosis of the external oblique, it is not directly derived from it.

 

Option B. Inguinal Ligament: The inguinal ligament is directly derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle. It is the inferior edge of the external oblique aponeurosis, stretching between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle. This ligament acts as a boundary between the anterior abdominal wall and the thigh, and structures like the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament in females pass beneath it to enter the inguinal canal.

 

Option C. Lacunar Ligament: Also called Gimbernat’s ligament, the lacunar ligament is a crescent-shaped fold of the aponeurosis of the external oblique that attaches to the pectineal line of the pubis. It's positioned medial to the inguinal ligament, and its formation is related to the deepening of the inguinal canal during development. It contributes to the posterior margin of the superficial inguinal ring and represents the lateral border of the femoral canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligaments derived from external oblique aponeurosis are:

questions.text: Identify the clinical sign shown in the image below:(NEET  PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Popeye sign

 

The above image depicts the popeye sign, which is caused by a rupture of the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii.

 

Popeye sign:

 

  • Description: This refers to the prominent bulge of the biceps muscle in the arm.
  • Cause: The sign is named after the cartoon character "Popeye the Sailor Man" who had bulging forearm muscles. It's observed in cases where there's a rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon. When the tendon ruptures, the muscle can sometimes ball up, creating a bulge in the mid-arm.
  • Clinical Relevance: Often accompanied by pain and weakness, it usually requires clinical evaluation to determine the need for surgical intervention.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs sign (or lesion):

 

  • Description: It is a compression fracture of the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head.
  • Cause: This lesion occurs when the humeral head impacts against the anterior glenoid rim during an anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • Clinical Relevance: The presence of a Hill-Sachs lesion can predispose an individual to recurrent shoulder dislocations. Its size and location may dictate treatment strategy in recurrent shoulder instability.

 

 

Option C. Griesinger sign:

 

  • Description: It refers to the presence of a postauricular sulcus or groove behind the ear.
  • Cause: This sign is seen in cases of acute mastoiditis, a complication of acute otitis media. The groove results from the edema and venous congestion in the sigmoid sinus secondary to the adjacent inflammation.
  • Clinical Relevance: Acute mastoiditis is a serious condition that requires prompt treatment, often including surgical intervention. The presence of Griesinger's sign helps in clinical diagnosis.

 

Option D. Rising sun sign:

 

  • Description: This is a radiological sign observed on imaging of the head.
  • Cause: It's seen in cases of tuberous sclerosis, a genetic disorder. On imaging, it refers to the appearance of subependymal nodules in the lateral ventricles that project into the ventricle. The nodules resemble the sun rising over the horizon.
  • Clinical Relevance: Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by the growth of benign tumors in many parts of the body. The presence of the "Rising sun" sign can help confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Popeye sign is a clinical indication of the rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon, leading to a characteristic bulging of the biceps muscle, which requires thorough clinical assessment and possibly surgical repair.

choices.text: Upper part of right inferior lobe

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the lung is affected when there is aspiration in supine position? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Upper part of right inferior lobe

 

When a person is in the supine position (lying on their back), aspirated material is most likely to enter the superior basel segment of the right lower lobe (upper part of the right inferior lobe). The right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and more vertically oriented than the left main bronchus. This makes the right side more susceptible to aspiration in general. And in the supine position, gravity makes the superior basel segment of the lower lobes (particularly on the right side) the most dependent and thus the most likely site for aspiration.

 

Aspiration of gastric contents can cause chemical pneumonitis or aspiration pneumonia, which can affect different parts of the lung depending on the patient's position during aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lingula: The lingula is a segment of the left upper lobe of the lung. It corresponds anatomically to the right middle lobe but on the left side. Due to the angulation of the main bronchi, it's less common for aspirated contents to travel into the left main bronchus when compared to the right. Thus, while it's possible for aspirated material to reach the lingula, especially in certain positions or conditions, it's not the most common site of aspiration.

 

Option C. Right superior lobe: This lobe isn't the primary location for aspiration in the supine position. However, if someone were to aspirate while standing or sitting upright, aspirated material might be more likely to enter the apical (uppermost) segments of the right upper lobe.

 

Option D. Right middle lobe: The right middle lobe, particularly its bronchus, is more susceptible to aspiration when an individual is in the lateral decubitus position (lying on their side). The lateral segment of the right middle lobe becomes the most dependent segment in this position. But again, in the supine position, the right middle lobe isn't the primary site of aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient is in a supine position and aspirates, superior segment of the inferior lobes are the most commonly involved lung sites.

questions.text: A person came to the OPD with a history of fall on the outstretched hand and now has an injury at the anatomical snuff box. Which bone is most commonly fractured at this site?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scaphoid

 

Explanation:

 

The scaphoid bone, which forms the floor of the anatomical snuff box, is the most common carpal bone to be fractured.

 

The scaphoid bone is the second most common bone to suffer avascular necrosis after the head of the femur. When a person falls on an outstretched hand, the force is transmitted through the wrist, making the scaphoid bone vulnerable to fracture. The anatomical snuff box is an important anatomical landmark with five different clinical points related to it.

 

 

 

To test for a scaphoid fracture, the "glass holding position" can be used, where the thumb adopts a specific position that stresses the scaphoid bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lunate: Although the lunate is a carpal bone, it is not the most commonly fractured bone at the anatomical snuff box site.

 

Option C. Trapezium: The trapezium is one of the bones that can be palpated in the anatomical snuff box ("then try to catch her, she means trapezium"), but it is not the most commonly fractured bone in this scenario.

 

Option D. Pisiform: The pisiform is a small carpal bone located on the ulnar side of the wrist, not in the anatomical snuff box, and is not commonly fractured in a fall on an outstretched hand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scaphoid bone, which forms the floor of the anatomical snuff box, is the most common carpal bone to be fractured when a person falls on an outstretched hand.

 

Note –

 

  • MC bone getting avascular necrosis – head of the femur
  • 2nd most common bone getting avascular necrosis – Scaphoid
  • MC carpal bone getting fractured - scaphoid

questions.text: Injury of the lower brachial plexus leads to Klumpke's paralysis. What is the characteristic clinical finding seen in this lesion? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Claw hand

 

The characteristic clinical finding in Klumpke's paralysis is a complete claw hand.

 

 

In Klumpke's paralysis, there's an injury to the lower brachial plexus, particularly affecting the C8 and T1 roots. This leads to weakness or paralysis of the small hand muscles, specifically those innervated by the ulnar nerve. Patients have hyperextension at the MCP joints and flexion at the IP joints of the 4th and 5th fingers, giving the appearance of a "claw hand". The "clawing" is most evident when the patient tries to extend the fingers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Policeman tip hand (also known as "Bishop's hand") : This deformity is characterized by hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexion of the interphalangeal (IP) joints of the 4th and 5th fingers. It's seen in situations where there's a combined injury to both the median and ulnar nerves. This term, however, is not as commonly used in modern medical literature.

 

Option B. Wrist drop : This is seen with injury to the radial nerve. A patient with wrist drop will have difficulty in extending the wrist and fingers. This can be due to injury or compression of the radial nerve anywhere along its course, but often it's associated with injury in the axillary or upper arm region.

 

Option D. Horner's syndrome: Injury to the lower brachial plexus, especially the T1 root, can also involve the sympathetic fibers leading to Horner's syndrome, which is characterized by miosis (constricted pupil), ptosis (drooping of the eyelid), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side. While Horner's syndrome can be associated with a Klumpke's injury, it is not the most characteristic clinical finding for Klumpke's paralysis. The claw hand is more directly related to the primary neural injury of Klumpke's paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klumpke's paralysis, also known as Dejerine-Klumpke palsy, is a type of brachial plexus injury that affects the lower brachial plexus nerves (C8 and T1) that control the muscles of the forearm and hand.

 

Causes:

 

  • Brachial plexus injury involving the C8 and T1 nerve roots.
  • This injury can occur during childbirth if excessive force is applied during delivery or if the infant's shoulder becomes impacted in the birth canal.
  • Trauma, such as a fall or car accident, can also cause a brachial plexus injury and lead to Klumpke's paralysis.
  • Other less common causes include tumors or inflammation in the area.

 

Symptoms

 

  • Weakness or paralysis of the muscles of the hand and forearm,
  • Numbness or tingling in the hand and fingers, and a weakened grip.
  • In severe cases, there may also be a loss of sensation in the affected arm.

 

Treatment may include physical therapy, occupational therapy, and in some cases, surgery.

questions.text: The given congenital anomaly develops due to non-fusion of:  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arch

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a preauricular sinus, a congenital anomaly characterized by a small opening or pit near the external ear. This condition arises due to incomplete fusion during embryonic development.

 

  1. Embryological Development: The external ear develops from six small hillocks of tissue that form around the 1st pharyngeal cleft, derived from the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches. These hillocks eventually merge to form the pinna (external ear).
  2. Non-fusion of Pharyngeal Arches: If there is incomplete or improper fusion between the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches, a preauricular sinus may form. This sinus can present as a small pit or dimple in front of the ear and can sometimes become infected or form cysts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2nd and 3rd pharyngeal arch: This is incorrect. The structures formed by the 2nd and 3rd pharyngeal arches do not contribute to the formation of the external ear and thus are not involved in the formation of preauricular sinuses.

 

Option C. 1st and 2nd pharyngeal pouch: This is incorrect. The pharyngeal pouches form internal structures such as the tonsils, thymus, and parts of the ear's auditory tube but are not involved in the formation of preauricular sinuses.

 

Option D. 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouch: This is incorrect. These pouches are involved in forming structures like the thymus and parathyroid glands and do not play a role in the formation of the external ear or preauricular sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preauricular sinuses result from the incomplete fusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches during embryonic development, leading to the formation of a small pit or tract near the external ear.

questions.text: What will be the symptoms of a fracture at the marked area? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anosmia

 

The marked area in the image corresponds to the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone, which is located at the base of the skull. The cribriform plate is a thin, perforated structure through which the olfactory nerves (Cranial Nerve I) pass from the nasal cavity to the olfactory bulbs.

 

If this area is fractured, it can lead to damage to the olfactory nerves, resulting in anosmia, which is the loss of the sense of smell. Anosmia is a common symptom associated with fractures of the cribriform plate, as the olfactory nerves are particularly vulnerable in this region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoacusis: Hypoacusis refers to reduced hearing ability and is typically associated with damage to the auditory structures or the auditory nerve (Cranial Nerve VIII). This symptom is not related to fractures of the cribriform plate.

 

Option B. Visual loss: Visual loss would occur due to damage to the optic nerve (Cranial Nerve II) or structures of the eye, not the cribriform plate. The optic nerve passes through the optic canal, not the cribriform plate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone can lead to anosmia due to damage to the olfactory nerves. This area is crucial for the sense of smell.

questions.text: A man complains of difficulty in standing up from a sitting position and scissoring gait was observed in him. Which nerve is damaged in this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obturator nerve

 

The obturator nerve innervates the adductor muscles of the thigh, such as the adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus, and gracilis muscles. These muscles are responsible for adducting the thigh (bringing it closer to the body's midline). When the obturator nerve is involved, adductor muscles of thigh are getting spasm , which can lead to a scissoring gait, where the legs cross over each other during walking. Additionally, patients may find it difficult to stabilize their lower limbs, which causes problems like standing up from a sitting position.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior gluteal nerve: Damage to this nerve typically causes a Trendelenburg gait, characterized by difficulty maintaining pelvic stability, rather than a scissoring gait.

 

Option B. Inferior gluteal nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus maximus, which is primarily involved in hip extension. Damage here would cause difficulty in rising from a sitting position but does not typically cause a scissoring gait.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve innervates the quadriceps, which are responsible for knee extension. Damage to the femoral nerve would cause difficulty in extending the knee but does not explain the scissoring gait pattern.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Involvement of obturator nerve may lead to spam of adductor muscles, causing a scissoring gait and difficulty rising from a sitting position due to the impaired function of the adductor muscles.

questions.text: All of the following cranial nerve nuclei are part of the General Somatic Afferent (GSA) column except? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Facial nerve

 

Explanation:

 

  • The facial nerve does not have a GSA component.
  • It contains the following components:
    • SVA: Taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via chorda tympani).
    • SVE: Motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression.
    • GVE: Parasympathetic innervation to lacrimal, submandibular, and sublingual glands.
  • The facial nerve lacks a general somatic sensory function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve (V):

 

  • The trigeminal nerve is the primary cranial nerve with a GSA component.
  • It carries touch, pain, and temperature sensations from the face.
  • The trigeminal ganglion (Gasserian ganglion) is its sensory ganglion.

 

Option C. Vagus nerve (X):

 

  • The vagus nerve has a GSA component, providing somatic sensation from:
    • The external ear.
    • Part of the external auditory meatus.
    • Part of the tympanic membrane.
  • It also contains GVA, SVA, and motor components.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX):

 

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve contains GSA fibers that provide somatic sensation from:
    • The external ear.
    • The upper pharynx.
    • The middle ear.
    • It also carries taste sensation and visceral sensory information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the sensory components of cranial nerves:
    • GSA: General somatic sensation (touch, pain, temperature).
    • SVA: Special senses (taste, smell).
    • GVA: Visceral sensation (from internal organs).
  • Clinical relevance:
    • Trigeminal neuralgia and facial pain syndromes.
    • Sensory testing during cranial nerve examination.
    • Recognizing referred pain patterns related to cranial nerves.

questions.text: What is the structure marked with black arrow in the given image: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1st pharyngeal arch

 

Explanation:

 

The marked structure in the image is identified as the malleus.

 

The first pharyngeal arch, also known as the mandibular arch, is responsible for the formation of several structures in the head and neck region.

 

  1. Malleus and Incus Formation: The 1st pharyngeal arch is crucial in forming the malleus and incus, two of the three auditory ossicles in the middle ear. The cartilage component of this arch, known as Meckel's cartilage, gives rise to these ossicles.
  2. Other Structures from the 1st Pharyngeal Arch: Apart from the malleus and incus, the 1st pharyngeal arch also contributes to the formation of the maxilla, mandible, sphenomandibular ligament, and parts of the middle ear, including the anterior malleolar ligament.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2nd pharyngeal arch: This is incorrect. The 2nd pharyngeal arch (hyoid arch) primarily forms the stapes (another auditory ossicle), styloid process, stylohyoid ligament, and parts of the hyoid bone.

 

Option C. 3rd pharyngeal arch: This is incorrect. The 3rd pharyngeal arch contributes to the formation of the greater horn and lower part of the hyoid bone.

 

Option D. neuroectoderm: This is incorrect in the context of the malleus. While neural crest cells, derived from neuroectoderm, play a significant role in the development of many craniofacial structures, the malleus specifically develops from the 1st pharyngeal arch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

1st arch cartilage: Meckle’s cartilage → 5 ‘M’

 

1. Malleus & Incus

2. Malleolar (Anterior) ligament

3. Spheno-Mandibular ligament

4. Mandible

5. Maxilla

 

2nd arch cartilage: Reichert cartilage → 5 ‘S’

 

1. Stapes (except footplate & Otic capsule)

2. Styloid process

3. Stylohyoid ligament

4. Smaller cornu of hyoid

5. Superior ½ of body of the hyoid

 

3rd arch cartilage:

 

1. Greater cornu of hyoid

2. Inferior ½ of hyoid

 

4th & 6th arch cartilage:

 

-  Laryngeal cartilage

questions.text: What is the most common anatomical site for a congenital diaphragmatic hernia? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterolateral


The most common site for congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the posterolateral aspect of the diaphragm, specifically on the left side. This type of hernia is known as the Bochdalek hernia, which occurs due to a failure of the pleuroperitoneal membrane to close properly during fetal development. This defect typically occurs on the left side because the liver provides a protective barrier on the right, making right-sided defects less common. Bochdalek hernias account for the majority of congenital diaphragmatic hernias.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterolateral: This location is associated with Morgagni hernia, which is less common and usually occurs on the right side near the sternum. It does not typically involve the posterolateral region, making it a less frequent site for congenital diaphragmatic hernias.

 

Option B. Central tendon: The central tendon of the diaphragm does not commonly present with congenital hernias, as it is primarily a strong fibrous part of the diaphragm, less prone to defects.

 

Option C. Crural: Crural defects are not commonly associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernias. These defects would more likely involve esophageal hernias rather than congenital diaphragmatic hernias.

 

Educational Objective:


The most common site for congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the posterolateral region, predominantly on the left side, known as the Bochdalek hernia.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of the right side of the face with the loss of pain and temperature. Pain and temperature sensation of the left leg is also lost. The lesion is most likely located at?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lateral pons

 

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral pontine syndrome which occurs due to a lesion located at lateral pons

 

 

Lateral Pons: Lesions here would affect:

 

  • The facial nerve or its nucleus leading to ipsilateral facial weakness. (differentiating feature from lateral medullary syndrome).
  • The spinothalamic tract leading to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial Medulla: Lesions here would affect:

 

  • The corticospinal tract leading to contralateral hemiparesis.
  • The medial lemniscus leading to contralateral loss of tactile and proprioceptive sensations.
  • The hypoglossal nerve leading to ipsilateral tongue deviation.
  • This doesn't match the patient's symptoms.

 

Option C. Medial Pons: Lesions here would affect:

 

  • The corticospinal tract causing contralateral hemiparesis.
  • The abducens nerve leading to ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle palsy.
  • The medial lemniscus causing contralateral loss of tactile and proprioceptive sensations.
  • This doesn't align with the symptoms presented.

 

Option D. Lateral Medulla: Lesions in this region (often due to Wallenberg syndrome or lateral medullary syndrome) would result in:

 

  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on the face due to the involvement of the descending tract and nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body due to the involvement of the spinothalamic tract.
  • Dysphagia, hoarseness, and decreased gag reflex due to the involvement of the nucleus ambiguus.
  • Vertigo, nausea, nystagmus due to vestibular nuclei involvement.
  • Ataxia and dysmetria because of the involvement of the inferior cerebellar peduncle.
  • While some symptoms match, the facial weakness characteristic of facial nerve involvement is not a feature of lateral medullary lesions.
  • If there was no mention of facial weakness then lateral medullary syndrome would had been the answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional Information

 

Stroke symptoms

 

Rule of 4’s

 

  1. 4 cranial nerves originate above pons (2 in midbrain), 4 in pons, 4 in medulla
  2. 4 midline cranial nerves (CN 3, 4, 6, 12) (divide equally into 12 except 1 and 2)
  3. 4 Midline structures that begin with M 
    • Motor pathway (aka corticospinal tract)
    • Medial lemniscus
    • Medial longitudinal fasciculus
    • Medial cranial nerves (CN 3, 4, 6, 12)
  4. 4 structures to the Side that begin with S 
    • Spinocerebellar pathway (ipsilateral ataxia of arm and leg)
    • Spinothalamic pathway
    • Sensory portion of CN V
    • Sympathetic pathway

choices.text: Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – I
Secondary oocyte completed in prophase – II
Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – II
Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase – II

questions.text: Following ovulation, the oocyte remains halted in which meiotic phase until fertilization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase – II
