After ovulation, the oocyte that is released is the secondary oocyte, which is arrested in metaphase II of meiosis. This arrest continues until fertilization occurs. During fertilization, the entry of sperm triggers the completion of meiosis II, leading to the formation of a mature ovum and the release of the second polar body.

 

This arrest in metaphase II is a crucial step in the reproductive cycle, ensuring that the oocyte is ready to complete meiosis only if fertilization occurs, which prevents the wasteful completion of meiosis without fertilization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – I: This phase describes the primary oocyte that is arrested in prophase I during fetal development and remains in this state until puberty. It is not involved in the post-ovulation phase.

 

Option B. Secondary oocyte completed in prophase – II: This option is incorrect because the secondary oocyte does not complete prophase II. It arrests in metaphase II after ovulation and only completes meiosis II if fertilization occurs.

 

Option C. Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – II: This is incorrect because the primary oocyte does not arrest in prophase II. It arrests in prophase I, and after puberty, it resumes meiosis to form a secondary oocyte.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase II at the time of ovulation and remains in this stage until fertilization occurs, highlighting a critical regulatory checkpoint in the female reproductive cycle.

questions.text: Injury to which of the following nerves most commonly results in foot drop? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Common peroneal nerve

 

Common Peroneal Nerve (also known as Common Fibular Nerve) is the nerve primarily responsible for foot drop when injured.

 

  • Origin: The common peroneal nerve is a branch of the sciatic nerve, which splits into the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve near the apex of the popliteal fossa.
  • Function: It innervates the muscles of the anterior and lateral compartments of the leg, such as the tibialis anterior, which dorsiflexes the ankle. An injury to this nerve can result in the inability to dorsiflex the foot, leading to "foot drop."
  • Common injury sites: This nerve can be compromised at the fibular head where it is superficial, making it susceptible to injuries.      

 

 

Hence, injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to:

 

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
  • Loss of eversion
  • Loss of extension of toes
  • Sensory loss
    • Anterior and lateral side of the leg
    • Dorsum of the foot including the medial side of the great toe

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Femoral Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Arises from the lumbar plexus and is composed of fibers from the L2 to L4 nerve roots.
  • Function: Primarily innervates the anterior thigh muscles like the quadriceps, which are responsible for knee extension. It also provides sensation to the anterior thigh and medial leg.
  • If injured: A person may have difficulty in extending the knee and reduced sensation in the innervation area, but it will not cause foot drop.

 

Option C. Tibial Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Another branch of the sciatic nerve.
  • Function: It innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg, which are primarily responsible for plantarflexion of the ankle and flexion of the toes.
  • If injured: A person may have difficulty in plantarflexing the ankle or flexing the toes and may have a loss of sensation in the sole of the foot, but foot drop is not a symptom.

 

Option D. Sciatic Nerve:

 

  • Origin: The largest nerve in the body, originating from the sacral plexus with roots from L4 to S3.
  • Function: Innervates much of the posterior thigh, all of the leg except for a small medial area, and most of the foot.
  • If injured: Since the sciatic nerve gives rise to both the tibial and common peroneal nerves, injury can cause a range of motor and sensory deficits in the leg, depending on the injury's location. However, an injury specifically leading to foot drop would more directly implicate its common peroneal branch rather than the entire sciatic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The joint between the sternum and 1st costal cartilage is? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Synarthrosis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The first sternocostal joint is a synarthrosis (fibrous joint)
  • It's characterized by direct fibrous tissue connection between the first costal cartilage and sternum
  • This joint is immobile, providing stability to the upper thoracic cage
  • This is the only sternocostal joint that is fibrous; all others are synovial

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibrocartilaginous Joint:

 

  • Fibrocartilaginous joints contain both fibrous and cartilaginous components
  • While the joint does involve cartilage, it's connected by fibrous tissue, not fibrocartilage
  • Examples of fibrocartilaginous joints include intervertebral discs, not found in the sternocostal region

 

Option B. Symphyseal Joint:

 

  • Symphyseal joints are secondary cartilaginous joints with a fibrocartilaginous disc
  • In the thoracic cage, symphyseal joints are found at the manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints
  • The first sternocostal joint lacks the characteristic fibrocartilaginous disc of symphyseal joints

 

Option C. Synovial Joint:

 

  • While most sternocostal joints (2nd-7th) are synovial
  • The first sternocostal joint is uniquely different, being fibrous
  • The absence of a synovial cavity and articular cartilage makes this option incorrect

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Different types of joints in the thoracic cage
  2. The unique nature of the first sternocostal joint
  3. The structural and functional significance of immobile joints in the upper thoracic cage
  4. Variations in joint types between different costal levels

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament
It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

 

  • Laterally, the fibres of the iliopubic tract fan out with fascia iliaca.
  • The iliopubic tract is a thickening of the transversalis fascia immediately posterior to the inguinal (Poupart's) ligament.
  • It runs superolaterally from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and arches across the front of the femoral sheath.

 

 

The muscle has a broad attachment medially into the pubic tubercle and pectineal line, situated behind the conjoint tendon. On the lateral side, its fibers spread out within the fascia transversalis and fascia iliac without being attached to the iliac spines.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract is not a thickening of the lumbar fascia. Instead, it is a thickened band of the iliopectineal fascia, which is an extension of the transversalis fascia. It runs parallel and posterior to the inguinal ligament (Poupart's ligament).

 

Option B. It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract runs parallel to and posterior to the inguinal ligament (also known as Poupart's ligament). It forms the inferior border of the internal inguinal ring and provides a posterior boundary for the femoral canal.

 

Option C. It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon: This statement is not accurate. The iliopubic tract doesn't insert into the pubic tubercle. Instead, it runs laterally from the pubic tubercle, posterior to the inguinal ligament, and continues as the iliopectineal arch or fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As the iliopubic tract moves laterally from the pubic tubercle, its fibers fan out and blend with the fascia of the iliacus muscle (often referred to as the iliac fascia or fascia iliaca). This provides a connection between the structures of the anterior abdominal wall and the pelvic sidewall.

questions.text:
Arrange the structures of the cubital fossa in sequence from medial to lateral? (INICET Nov 2022)

 

1. Median nerve

2. Radial nerve

3. Tendon of biceps brachi

4. Brachial artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1,4,3,2

 

Explanation:

 

The structures are arranged in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral as follows:

 

1. Median nerve

2. Brachial artery

3. Tendon of biceps brachii

4. Radial nerve (Superficial Branch of radial nerve)

Mnemonic is MBBR
 

 

 

The cubital fossa is actually a triangular area located on the anterior aspect of the elbow, not the upper forearm. It is bounded by several structures, including:

 

  • The lateral border of the pronator teres muscle, which forms the medial boundary
  • The medial border of the brachioradialis muscle, which forms the lateral boundary
  • The imaginary line connecting the epicondyles of the humerus, which forms the superior boundary
  • The floor of the cubital fossa is formed by the brachialis and supinator muscles, while the roof is formed by the Deep fascia of the skin.
  • The roof of cubital fossa contains Subcutaneous veins which are used for routine phlebotomy procedures. These veins are - median cubital vein, cephalic vein and basilic vein

 

The cubital fossa contains several important structures, including the brachial artery, radial nerve, and median nerve. It is a common site for blood draws and intravenous catheter placement due to the relatively superficial location of the structures and ease of access.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct anatomical sequencing of structures in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral—median nerve, brachial artery, tendon of biceps brachii, and radial nerve—is essential for both anatomical education and practical clinical applications.

questions.text:
Arrange the cells according to their positions from the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules? (INICET Nov 2022)

 

1. Spermatogonia

2. Primary spermatocyte

3. Spermatid

4. Spermatozoa

5. Myoepithelial cell
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 5,1,2,3,4

 

From the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules, the cells are arranged in the order of:

 

  • Myoepithelial cells
  • Spermatogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte
  • Spermatid
  • Spermatozoa

 

In the seminiferous tubules, cells are organized in a specific sequence from the basal layer towards the lumen as part of the spermatogenesis process. The order reflects the developmental stages of sperm cells:

 

5. Myoepithelial cells: These cells, located at the basal layer, support the structure and function of the seminiferous tubules.

 

1. Spermatogonia: These are the stem cells located just above the basal membrane, which undergo mitotic divisions to produce more spermatogonia or differentiate into primary spermatocytes.

 

2. Primary spermatocytes:  Situated above the spermatogonia, these cells undergo meiosis I to form secondary spermatocytes.

 

3. Spermatid: Derived from the secondary spermatocytes after meiosis II, these cells are closer to the lumen and undergo spermiogenesis to become spermatozoa.

 

4. Spermatozoa: These are the final, mature male gametes that are nearest to the lumen of the tubule, ready to be released into the reproductive tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

From the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules, the cells are arranged in the order of:

 

  • Myoepithelial cells
  • Spermatogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte
  • Spermatid
  • Spermatozoa

choices.text: Anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery
Anterior cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery
Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery
Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery

questions.text: What is the blood supply of the structure marked with the arrow in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery

 

The corpus callosum is the largest fibre pathway in the brain. The corpus callosum is composed of the rostrum, genu, trunk or body, and splenium.

 

The corpus callosum is a large bundle of nerve fibers that connects the two hemispheres of the brain and allows for communication between them. It is supplied with blood by the anterior cerebral artery and the anterior communicating artery, which are both branches of the internal carotid artery.

 

The anterior cerebral artery supplies blood to the front and top of the brain, including the medial surface of the cerebral hemispheres, which is where the corpus callosum is located. The anterior communicating artery connects the two anterior cerebral arteries and provides additional blood supply to the corpus callosum. Damage to the corpus callosum, such as from a stroke or traumatic brain injury, can disrupt communication between the two hemispheres and lead to a range of neurological symptoms depending on the location and severity of the damage.

 

The corpus callosum is the major commissural pathway connecting the cerebral hemispheres that receives its blood supply from anterior communicating artery, pericallosal artery, and posterior pericallosal artery”.

 

“Pericallosal artery is formed by branches of from anterior and posterior cerebral arteries (Mainly anterior cerebral artery). Pericallosal arteries which are derived from anterior cerebral arteries supply the anterior 4/5th of corpus callosum and posterior 1/5th is supplied by pericallosal artery derived from posterior cerebral artery.”

 

Since the arrow is near the posterior end of body answer is ACommA + ACA
If the arrow was near the anterior end, answer will be ACommA + ACA
If the arrow is on splenium, the answer will be ACA + PCA
 

 

 

   

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery: The anterior cerebral artery does supply the corpus callosum, but the middle cerebral artery does not play a significant role in its blood supply.

 

Option B. Anterior cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery: While the anterior cerebral artery supplies the corpus callosum, the posterior cerebral artery primarily supplies the posterior parts of the brain, including the occipital lobes. It doesn't contribute significantly to the blood supply of the corpus callosum.

 

Option D. Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery: Neither the middle cerebral artery nor the posterior cerebral artery is the primary supplier of blood to the corpus callosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corpus callosum's blood supply is primarily provided by the anterior cerebral artery, with additional support from the anterior communicating artery. This knowledge is crucial in understanding potential impacts of circulatory issues within the brain, such as strokes, which could affect interhemispheric communication.

questions.text: Which type of sensation is carried by the 2nd order neuron of the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pain

 

The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve is responsible for transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the face to the brain. The second-order neurons in this nucleus relay these sensations to higher brain centers for processing. This pathway is crucial for the perception of painful stimuli and temperature changes, ensuring appropriate responses to potential dangers or injuries.

 

Note -

 

  • The trigeminal nerve has two types of nuclei: a motor nucleus and sensory nuclei.
  • The motor nucleus is singular and located in the pons.
  • The sensory nuclei are more numerous, consisting of three different nuclei distributed within the brainstem:
    • Mesencephalic Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (MNT): This nucleus is situated in the midbrain and is part of the sensory nuclei.
    • Chief Sensory Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (CNT): Located in the pons, this nucleus primarily handles the main sensory functions of the trigeminal nerve.
    • Spinal Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (also referred to as SNT): This extends down to the medulla and is involved with transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the face to the brain.
  • Four nuclei: (3 sensory +1 Motor).
  • General somatic afferent:
    1. Mesencephalic (midbrain & pons): receives proprioceptive fibers from face
    2. Principal (main) sensory (pons): receives touch fibers from face.
    3. Spinal (pons, medulla & upper 2-3 cervical segments of spinal cord): receives pain & temperature sensations from face.
  • Special visceral efferent:

4. Motor nucleus (pons): supplies:

  • Four muscles of mastication (temporalis, masseter, medial & lateral pterygoid).
  • Other four muscles (Anterior belly of diagstic, mylohyoid, tensor tympani & tensor palati).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proprioception: Proprioception is managed by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus. This nucleus is responsible for sensing the position and movement of the jaw muscles, contributing to reflexes such as the jaw jerk.

 

Option B. Touch: The chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve handles the sensation of touch. This nucleus receives tactile information from the face and transmits it to the brain.

 

Option D. Vibration: Vibration sense is also managed by the chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. This nucleus is involved in processing detailed touch and vibratory sensations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve carries pain and temperature sensations, distinguishing it from the other nuclei responsible for proprioception, touch, and vibration.

questions.text: During the surgical procedure for patent ductus arteriosus, which structure in close relation to it can be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left recurrent laryngeal nerve

 

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a congenital heart defect where the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth, leaving an open connection between the aorta and the pulmonary artery. Surgical correction of this defect involves closing the ductus arteriosus.

 

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, loops under the arch of the aorta near the ligamentum arteriosum (the remnant of the ductus arteriosus). Due to its close proximity to the ductus arteriosus, this nerve is at risk of being damaged during surgical procedures aimed at correcting PDA. Injury to this nerve can result in hoarseness, voice changes, or even vocal cord paralysis due to its role in innervating the muscles of the larynx.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagus nerve: While the vagus nerve is in the vicinity, it does not have the same close relationship with the ductus arteriosus as the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. The vagus nerve primarily runs along the side of the neck and thorax without looping directly near the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option C. Right recurrent laryngeal nerve: The right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops under the right subclavian artery and does not pass near the ductus arteriosus, making it less likely to be damaged during surgery on the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option D. Phrenic nerve: The phrenic nerve, which innervates the diaphragm, runs more anteriorly in the thorax and does not have a close anatomical relationship with the ductus arteriosus, thus it is not at significant risk during PDA surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is at significant risk of injury during surgical procedures for patent ductus arteriosus due to its close anatomical relationship with the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that arises from the marked part? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Abducens nerve

 

The image shows the abducens nerve.

 

Origin: The abducens nerve originates in the pons. Its fibers arise from the abducens nucleus, which is located in the dorsal pons near the floor of the fourth ventricle.

 

Exit Point: It emerges from the ventral surface of the brainstem at the junction between the pons and the medulla, in the groove between the pons and the pyramid of the medulla.

 

Function: It innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor Nerve (III)

 

  • Origin: The oculomotor nerve originates in the anterior aspect of the midbrain. Specifically, its fibers arise from the oculomotor nucleus, which is located in the superior colliculus of the midbrain.
  • Exit Point: After emerging from the midbrain, it exits the brainstem at the level of the interpeduncular fossa (the space between the cerebral peduncles).
  • Function: It innervates most of the muscles controlling eye movements. It also contains parasympathetic fibers that are involved in pupil constriction and the lens's accommodation.

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal Nerve (IX)

 

  • Origin: The glossopharyngeal nerve arises from the medulla oblongata, specifically from the postolivary sulcus, which lies lateral to the olive.
  • Exit Point: It exits the brainstem in a groove between the olive and the inferior cerebellar peduncle, alongside the vagus (X) and accessory (XI) nerves.
  • Function: It has several roles, including taste from the posterior third of the tongue, sensation from the upper pharynx, and innervation of the stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Option D. Facial Nerve (VII)

 

  • Origin: The facial nerve arises from the pons. Specifically, its fibers come from the facial nerve nucleus.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle, between the pons and the medulla. It exits lateral to the abducens nerve and medial to the vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).
  • Function: The facial nerve controls the muscles of facial expression. It also has taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and carries parasympathetic fibers to salivary and lacrimal glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The abducens nerve, also known as cranial nerve VI, arises from the abducens nucleus in the pontomedullary junction, which is located in the lower part of the pons and upper part of the medulla oblongata in the brainstem. It exits the brainstem at the junction of the pons and medulla oblongata and travels through the cavernous sinus to innervate the lateral rectus muscle of the eye. Its main function is to control eye movement and allow for horizontal gaze.

questions.text: Apocrine glands are present in which of the following?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Axilla

 

 

 

Apocrine glands are a type of sweat gland that are primarily found in certain areas of the body. These glands release their secretions in response to emotional stress or hormonal changes. They are different from the more common eccrine sweat glands, which are distributed throughout most of the body and are primarily involved in temperature regulation.

 

  • Axilla: Apocrine glands are predominantly located in the axilla (underarm) region. They become active during puberty and release a thicker, milky secretion that can produce body odor when broken down by skin bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Face: The face contains sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands, but not apocrine glands.

 

Option B. Scalp: The scalp contains numerous sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands, but apocrine glands are not typically found in this area.

 

Option C. Palms and soles: The palms and soles have a high concentration of eccrine sweat glands, which are crucial for thermoregulation. Apocrine glands are not found in these regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apocrine glands are primarily found in the axilla (underarm) region and become active during puberty, releasing thicker secretions that can lead to body odor when metabolized by skin bacteria.

questions.text: During which week of embryonic development does cardiac activity typically commence? (NEET PG  2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4th week

 

By the fourth week, the early heart begins to form and starts its contractions. The heart develops from a simple linear tube into a looping structure during this time. This looping eventually gives rise to the various chambers of the heart. Towards the end of the 4th week, the heart starts to beat and pump blood. However, it's worth noting that while the heart starts to beat during this week, the full structure of the heart with its four chambers isn't fully developed yet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2nd week: During the second week of embryonic development, formation of the bilaminar embryonic disc takes place, which consists of the epiblast and hypoblast. Additionally, events like the formation of the amniotic cavity, yolk sac and gastrulation begins towards the end of this week. At this point, the heart has not yet begun to form, and thus, there's no heart beating during the 2nd week.

 

Option C. 6th week: By the sixth week, the heart's development has progressed further. The interatrial and interventricular septa are beginning to form. While the heart is beating and becoming more sophisticated in its function, it had already started its contractions in the 4th week.

 

Option D. 10th week: By the 10th week, the embryonic period is concluding, and the fetal period is about to commence. The heart is much more developed, with more defined chambers and valves. Most major organs and external structures are formed by this time, and the fetus looks unmistakably human.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The heart starts to beat in the 4th week of development.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Abductor hallucis
  2. Flexor digitorum accessorius
  3. Flexor hallucis brevis
  4. First lumbrical
  5. First interossei
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 5

 

 

 

The lateral plantar nerve is a branch of the tibial nerve, which innervates various muscles in the sole of the foot. It divides into superficial and deep branches, each supplying specific muscles.

 

  • Flexor Digitorum Accessorius : This muscle assists in the flexion of the toes and is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.
  • First Interossei: The interossei muscles, which include the dorsal and plantar interossei, are responsible for abduction and adduction of the toes. The first interossei is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Abductor hallucis: This muscle is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, not the lateral plantar nerve.

 

3. Flexor hallucis brevis: This muscle is also supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

 

4. First lumbrical: The first lumbrical is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, whereas the second, third, and fourth lumbricals are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral plantar nerve supplies the flexor digitorum accessorius (quadratus plantae) and the first interossei muscles in the foot.

questions.text: Following an accident, a patient presented with an inability to flex the MCP joint and extend the IP joint of his hand. Which nerve is damaged here? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulnar nerve

 

The patient’s symptoms of being unable to flex the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extend the interphalangeal (IP) joints suggest a problem with the lumbrical muscles. The lumbricals are responsible for these movements. Specifically, the third and fourth lumbrical muscles, which flex the MCP joints and extend the IP joints of the ring and little fingers, are innervated by the ulnar nerve. Damage to the ulnar nerve can result in a condition known as "claw hand," where these functions are compromised, leading to the inability to perform the described movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve: The radial nerve primarily controls the extension of the wrist and fingers, but not the flexion of the MCP joints or extension of the IP joints. Hence, it is not involved in this condition.

 

Option B. Anterior interosseous nerve: This is a branch of the median nerve, primarily responsible for the motor function of some of the deep muscles in the forearm but does not innervate the lumbricals. Therefore, it is not responsible for the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve: This nerve innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm, responsible for elbow flexion, but it does not play a role in the movement of the fingers or hand. Therefore, it is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ulnar nerve is responsible for innervating the third and fourth lumbricals, which are essential for flexing the MCP joints and extending the IP joints. Damage to this nerve can lead to the characteristic "claw hand" deformity.

questions.text: What is the root value of cremasteric reflex? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. L1, L2

 

Explanation:

 

The cremasteric reflex is mediated through the sensory fibers of the ilioinguinal nerve (L1) and the motor fibers of the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2). When the inner thigh is stroked, sensory impulses travel via the ilioinguinal nerve to the spinal cord segments L1 and L2, and motor impulses from these segments, through the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve, cause the cremaster muscle to contract, pulling the testicles upward.

 

The cremasteric reflex's afferent and efferent branches:

 

  • Afferent - Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Efferent - Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T8, T9: These thoracic spinal nerve roots primarily innervate the muscles and skin of the thoracic region and contribute to the intercostal nerves. They are not involved in the cremasteric reflex.

 

Option C. L3, L4: These lumbar spinal nerve roots are primarily associated with the front of the thigh and the medial side of the leg and foot. The femoral nerve, which is the largest nerve arising from the lumbar plexus, is derived from these roots. These roots are not directly involved in the cremasteric reflex but are important for the patellar (knee-jerk) reflex.

 

Option D. S1, S2: These sacral spinal nerve roots play a major role in innervating the posterior thigh, most of the leg and foot, and the perineum. They contribute to the sciatic nerve, among others. Reflexes like the ankle jerk (Achilles reflex) involve these nerve roots. They are not associated with the cremasteric reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cremasteric reflex is mediated by L1 and L2. In this reflex, there is ipsilateral elevation of the testicle following stroking of the medial thigh.

 

Other clinical reflexes and their root values: -

 

Achilles reflex – S1, S2

Patellar reflex – L3, L4

Biceps and brachio-radialis reflexes – C5, C6

Triceps reflex – C7, C8

Anal wink reflex – S3, S4

Abdominal reflex – T7 – T12

questions.text: Identify the brain malformation shown in the given MRI image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arnold Chiari malformation

 

Arnold Chiari malformation is a condition where there is herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This malformation is characterized by downward displacement of the cerebellum, particularly the tonsils, which can be observed on MRI scans as a distinctive pattern of herniation below the level of the foramen magnum. The provided radiograph shows this exact presentation, with cerebellar tissue extending through the foramen magnum, indicating Arnold Chiari malformation.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corpus callosal agenesis: This condition involves the complete or partial absence of the corpus callosum, the structure that connects the two cerebral hemispheres. This malformation would not present with cerebellar herniation on imaging but would show an absence of the corpus callosum on MRI.

 

Option B. Vein of Galen malformation: This is a vascular malformation involving an abnormal connection between cerebral arteries and veins. It would appear as a large, dilated venous structure on imaging and would not show herniation of the cerebellum.

 

Option C. Dandy Walker malformation: This condition is characterized by cystic enlargement of the fourth ventricle, partial or complete absence of the cerebellar vermis, and enlargement of the posterior fossa.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arnold Chiari malformation is identified by the herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, visible on MRI scans as the downward displacement of cerebellar tissue.

choices.text: Failure of closure of neural tube at week 3 intra-uterine life
Failure of closure of neural tube at week 4 intra-uterine life
Failure of closure of cranial neuropore at week 4 intra-uterine life
Failure of closure of caudal neuropore at week 4 intra-uterine life

questions.text: The following anomaly occurs due to (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Failure of closure of cranial neuropore at week 4 intra-uterine life

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a condition known as anencephaly, a severe neural tube defect characterized by the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp. This condition arises due to the failure of the cranial (anterior) neuropore to close during embryonic development.

 

  1. Neural Tube Development: The neural tube forms from the neural plate, which folds to create the neural groove and eventually closes to form the neural tube. This process begins around the third week of intrauterine life and continues into the fourth week.
  2. Closure of Neuropores: The neural tube has two openings, the cranial (anterior) and caudal (posterior) neuropores. The cranial neuropore normally closes by the 25th day of gestation (around the 4th week), while the caudal neuropore closes by the 28th day (also around the 4th week).
  3. Anencephaly: When the cranial neuropore fails to close, the result is anencephaly. This defect prevents the proper formation of the forebrain, resulting in the absence of major portions of the brain and skull.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Failure of closure of neural tube at week 3 intra-uterine life: This is incorrect because the neural tube begins to close around the third week, but the critical closure of the cranial neuropore occurs in the fourth week.

 

Option B. Failure of closure of neural tube at week 4 intra-uterine life: This is partially correct but not specific. The specific failure involved in anencephaly is the closure of the cranial neuropore, not just any part of the neural tube.

 

Option D. Failure of closure of caudal neuropore at week 4 intra-uterine life: This is incorrect as it refers to the closure of the caudal neuropore, which would lead to defects like spina bifida, not anencephaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly results from the failure of the cranial (anterior) neuropore to close by the 25th day of gestation, which occurs around the 4th week of intrauterine life.

questions.text: Identify the structure indicated by the arrow:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory bronchus

 

 

 

The image shows a histological section of the lung with an arrow indicating a structure involved in gas exchange. The key features to identify include the presence of air spaces and the type of epithelium lining these spaces.

 

  • Respiratory Bronchus: This structure is part of the respiratory zone of the lung, where gas exchange occurs. It is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium transitioning to simple squamous epithelium as it progresses into the alveolar ducts and sacs. The respiratory bronchus is characterized by the presence of alveoli arising from its walls, indicating the start of the gas exchange process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar sac: Alveolar sacs are the terminal ends of the respiratory tree where clusters of alveoli are found. They are not the initial structures for gas exchange but are rather the sites where the alveoli are grouped.

 

Option C. Terminal bronchiole: Terminal bronchioles are the last part of the conducting zone and do not participate in gas exchange. They are lined with simple cuboidal epithelium without the presence of alveoli in their walls.

 

Option D. Intrapulmonary bronchiole: Intrapulmonary bronchioles refer to the bronchioles within the lung tissue that are part of the conducting zone and do not participate directly in gas exchange.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The respiratory bronchus is the structure where gas exchange begins in the lung, identified by its simple cuboidal epithelium and the presence of alveoli arising from its walls.

questions.text: A female patient presented with the complaint of pain over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh after normal vaginal delivery. Which nerve is injured in this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral cutaneous nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, descending behind the inguinal ligament and running along the lateral part of the thigh, is the nerve likely injured in this clinical scenario.

The key clue is the patient's complaint of pain over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh following normal vaginal delivery. Compression of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh can lead to a condition called meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain along the lateral aspect of the thigh. The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh originates from the L2 and L3 nerve roots of the lumbar plexus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: Although the femoral nerve also has the same root values (L2, L3, L4) as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, it is formed by the posterior divisions of these nerves. The femoral nerve primarily supplies the hip joint, not the skin over the anterolateral thigh.

 

Option C. Obturator nerve: The obturator nerve is formed by the anterior divisions of the L2, L3, and L4 nerves. It mainly supplies the knee joint, and its referred pain is felt at the site of the femoral nerve. It is not responsible for the pain in the anterolateral thigh.

 

Option D. Gluteal nerve: The gluteal nerve is not related to the lumbar plexus or the anterolateral thigh region. It is not the nerve injured in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, originating from the L2 and L3 nerve roots, can be compressed, leading to meralgia paresthetica, which presents with burning pain, numbness & tingling over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh.
